title: If a attorney calls you cause of a pass bill and you don't answer the phone what happens and your disabled?
question: my husband was in the hopsital and acumulated bills and we cant pay them what do i do
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Types of personal injuries
answers: If you really can’t pay, talk to the attorney. Many of us forgive bills when there is a good reason.

I'd refer you to a debt collection DEFENSE attorney to review your situation and the nature of the medical debts. If he was disabled and presented his Medi-Cal card or advised them that the injuries were from the workplace and that it is part of a Workers Comp claim, then there should not be any debt collection efforts by those medical providers and you should retain an attorney to stop the harassing calls.

If these medical bills are for unpaid insurance deductibles or he had no insurance and it was not part of either Medi-Cal or Workers Comp, then it is possible the debt collectors who are unable to make a satisfactory payment arrangement might file a lawsuit against him, even if the debt amount is under $10,000. For that you should consult with a debt collection DEFENSE attorney, as well, to see if the accounts can be resolved. Your husband's situation of being disabled may help get these debts resolved. He probably qualifies for free legal assistance from a legal services organization.

In the immediate context, nothing happens. However, the lawyer could likely send the bills to collection after s/he adheres to whatever procedural requirements the California State Bar has imposed for collection of legal fees. Many state bars require counsel to first try to establish a payment plan, or to notify the client of the state bar's fee dispute service (if one exists) before pursuing the unpaid bills further. I recommend that you try to work out a payment plan with counsel as Attorney Doland suggested, but not doing so will not necessarily make this issue go away. I hope that your husband's health rebounds soon. Best wishes to you both.

Nothing happens if you don't answer the phone. It doesn't make anything better or worse.
You could try to work out a payment plan, or not.
